title: Authors and Citation
text: Benjamin Fallmann. Author, maintainer. Martin Posch. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Fallmann B, Posch M (2026). adagraph: Design Adaptive Trials Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure. R package version 0.1.2, https://nebtu.github.io/adagraph/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {adagraph: Design Adaptive Trials with a Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure},   author = {Benjamin Fallmann and Martin Posch},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.2},   url = {https://nebtu.github.io/adagraph/}, }

what: Design Adaptive Trials with a Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure
title: Design Adaptive Trials with a Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure
text: Design two-stage adaptive trial using graph-based closed-testing sequence, controlling FWER using conditional error rate method.

title: Design Adaptive Trials with a Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure
text: can install development version adagraph GitHub :
code: # install.packages("pak") pak::pak("nebtu/adagraph")

title: Design Adaptive Trials with a Graph-Based Closed Testing Procedure
code: library(adagraph)  alpha_spending_f <- function(x, t) 2 - 2 * pnorm(qnorm(1 - x / 2) / sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(   correlation = rbind(H1 = c(1, NA), H2 = c(NA, 1)),   weights = c(2 / 3, 1 / 3),   alpha = 0.05,   test_m = rbind(c(0, 1), c(1, 0)),   alpha_spending_f = alpha_spending_f,   t = 0.5 )   design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.001, 0.02)) |>   cer_drop_hypotheses(c(TRUE, FALSE)) |>   cer_final_test(c(NA, 0.01))  design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.001 0.020 #> Hypotheses rejected at the interim: 1 #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0 1 #>  #> New graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    0 #> [2,]    0    0 #>  #> ── Final test result ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Overall p-values of the hypotheses are: #> [1] 1.00 0.01 #> Hypotheses rejected:  #> [1] 1 2

what: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
title: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
text: Make new (generic) trial design

title: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
code: adagraph_design(   correlation = matrix(),   weights = double(),   alpha = double(),   test_m = matrix() )

title: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
text: correlation Correlation matrix describing structure correlations different hypotheses, use NA uncorrelated weights List weights, measuring important hypothesis alpha Single number, measuring total alpha spent FWER test_m Transition matrix describing graph closed test procedure test hypotheses

title: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
text: object class adagraph_design

title: Make a new (generic) trial design — adagraph_design
code: design <- adagraph_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0))) design #> A Adagraph Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>

what: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
text: Adapt trial design interim test

title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
code: cer_adapt(   design,   weights = NULL,   test_m = NULL,   time = NULL,   correlation = NULL,   adapt_bounds = TRUE )

title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
text: design cer_design object weights New weights vector Note lenght prespecified design dropping hypotheses, set according weights 0 use cer_drop_hypotheses() test_m Adapted test matrix defining graph closed test procedure test hypotheses time adapted information fraction first stage test occured. Note can now vector different value different hypotheses single value correlation adapted correlation matrix adapt_bounds Adapt bounds rejecting hypotheses keep FWER new adaptions. multiple adaptions, enough adapt bounds last one, call adapt_bounds() manually .

title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
text: object class cer_design, adaptions applied.

title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
text: adaptions, adapt_bounds needs used , last adaption. , either make sure adapt_bounds TRUE, use adapt_bounds() function manually

title: Adapt the trial design after the interim test — cer_adapt
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  #note that it is not necessary to do an interim test before, #but that an interim test will only be done with the prespecified parameters design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.1, 0.02))  design <- cer_adapt(design, weights = c(1/3, 2/3)) design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.10 0.02 #> No Hypotheses were rejected at the interim #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.3333333 0.6666667 #>

what: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
title: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
text: function calculates new bounds p-values final test. run finishing adaptions interim test, adapt_bounds option true last adaption anyway.

title: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
code: cer_adapt_bounds(design)

title: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
text: design cer_design object

title: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
text: cer_design object, new bounds calculated

title: Adjust bounds after changing some design parameters — cer_adapt_bounds
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.1, 0.02))  design <- cer_drop_hypotheses(design, c(TRUE, FALSE)) design <- cer_adapt_bounds(design)  design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.10 0.02 #> No Hypotheses were rejected at the interim #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0 1 #>  #> New graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    0 #> [2,]    0    0 #>

what: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
text: weights dropped hypotheses set 0 distributed proportionally previous weight hypotheses. means weights "stay ", adapted still sum 1. Note method lead adapted graph coherent actual weight distribution, may lead problems line

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
code: cer_alt_drop_hypotheses(design, hypotheses, adapt_bounds = TRUE)

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
text: design cer_design object hypotheses vector booleans indicating hypotheses dropped adapt_bounds Adapt bounds rejecting hypotheses keep FWER new adaptions. multiple adaptions, enough adapt bounds last one, call adapt_bounds() manually .

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
text: design specified hypotheses dropped (TRUE means hypothesis dropped)

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses, with a simplified strategy for redistributing weights — cer_alt_drop_hypotheses
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.1, 0.02))  design <- cer_alt_drop_hypotheses(design, c(TRUE, FALSE)) design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.10 0.02 #> No Hypotheses were rejected at the interim #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0 1 #>

what: Make a new CER trial design — cer_design

title: Make a new CER trial design — cer_design
code: cer_design(   correlation = matrix(),   weights = double(),   alpha = double(),   test_m = matrix(),   alpha_spending_f = function() {  },   t = double(),   seq_bonf = TRUE )

title: Make a new CER trial design — cer_design
text: correlation Correlation matrix describing structure correlations different hypotheses, use NA uncorrelated weights List weights, measuring important hypothesis alpha Single number, measuring total alpha spent FWER test_m Transition matrix describing graph closed test procedure test hypotheses alpha_spending_f alpha spending function, taking parameters alpha (overall spent alpha) t (information fraction interim test) t numeric 0 1 specifing planned time fraction interim test seq_bonf automatically reject hypotheses second stage sum PCER greater 1

title: Make a new CER trial design — cer_design
text: object class cer_design

title: Make a new CER trial design — cer_design
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>

what: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
text: weights dropped hypotheses set 0 distributed according prespecified graph. However, time fraction adapted, needs done manually desired.

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
code: cer_drop_hypotheses(design, hypotheses, adapt_bounds = TRUE)

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
text: design cer_design object hypotheses vector booleans indicating hypotheses dropped adapt_bounds Adapt bounds rejecting hypotheses keep FWER new adaptions. multiple adaptions, enough adapt bounds last one, call adapt_bounds() manually .

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
text: design specified hypotheses dropped (TRUE means hypothesis dropped)

title: Adapt a cer design by dropping hypotheses — cer_drop_hypotheses
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.1, 0.02))  design <- cer_drop_hypotheses(design, c(TRUE, FALSE)) design #> A CER Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.6666667 0.3333333 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>    [,1] [,2] #> H1    1   NA #> H2   NA    1 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.10 0.02 #> No Hypotheses were rejected at the interim #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0 1 #>  #> New graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    0 #> [2,]    0    0 #>

what: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
text: Test cer design early rejection hypotheses calculate CER adaptions

title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
code: cer_final_test(design, p_values, combined = TRUE)

title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
text: design cer_design object p_values list p-values hypotheses combined p-values already combination p-value first second stage just raw values second stage

title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
text: cer_design object, now also includes rejection status hypotheses final test

title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_final_test
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.001, 0.02))  design <- cer_drop_hypotheses(design, c(TRUE, FALSE)) design <- cer_adapt_bounds(design)  design <- cer_final_test(design, c(NA, 0.01)) design$rej #> [1] TRUE TRUE

title: Test a cer design for early rejection of hypotheses and calculate the CER for adaptions — cer_interim_test
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.001, 0.02)) design$rej_interim #> [1]  TRUE FALSE design$cer_vec #> [1] 0.3833001 1.0000000 1.0000000

what: Calculate bounds for preplanned test — cer_prep_bounds

title: Calculate bounds for preplanned test — cer_prep_bounds
code: cer_prep_bounds(correlation, weights, alpha, t)

title: Calculate bounds for preplanned test — cer_prep_bounds
text: correlation matrix describing correlation structure hypotheses weights list weights given hypotheses, length hypotheses alpha list length 2 describing amount alpha spent test hypotheses adhere first second stage respectively t information fraction first stage test planned

title: Calculate bounds for preplanned test — cer_prep_bounds
text: list following elements: bounds_1: vector length weights bounds first interim test cJ1: number gets multiplied weights get bounds_1 bounds_1: vector lenght weights bounds planned final test cJ2: number gets multiplied weights get bounds_2

title: Calculate bounds for preplanned test — cer_prep_bounds

what: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
text: CER design, see defined test sequence consonant, either just graph weights, also using correlation structure, adaption.

title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
code: check_consonance(   design,   adapted = design$adaptions,   stage = "both",   weights = FALSE )

title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
text: design cer_design object adapted Boolean, use adapted original values stage stage consonance tested? Can one "", "interim", "final". effect weights = TRUE. weights Boolean, TRUE uses weights instead actual bounds. correlation structure used, else checks consonance counterfactual graph used , use correlation structure made

title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
text: boolean value, TRUE design (specified weights) consonant, else FALSE

title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
text: every combination hypothesis design, intersection hypothesis built keeping specified alpha level, intersection hypothesis holding specific hypothesis rejected, hypothesis rejected. Consonance now means whenever intersection hypothesis rejected, least one intersection hypothesis superset one rejected. design consonant, sense optimal

title: Check if a design is consonant — check_consonance
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- cer_design(  correlation=rbind(H1=c(1, NA),                    H2=c(NA, 1)),  weights=c(2/3, 1/3),  alpha=0.05,  test_m=rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f=as,  t=0.5)  check_consonance(design) #> [1] TRUE check_consonance(design, stage = "final") #> [1] TRUE

what: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
text: Gives CER (condtional error rate) given set hypotheses, arbitrary weights correlation hypotheses. upper bound probabilty rejecting hypotheses weight greater 0 null hypothesis conditional stage one data, assuming reject whenever final p-value smaller cJ2 * weight assumes reject interim already, case 1 anyway.

title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
code: get_cer(p_values, weights, cJ2, correlation, t)

title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
text: p_values vector stage 1 p-values hypothesis weights weight give hypothesis, ignoring weight 0 cJ2 factor used deciding hypothesis rejected correlation matrix describing potential known correlation structure hypotheses. Use NA unkown correlations t information time fraction interim test performed

title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
text: single number greater 0, CER

title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
text: Note correlation values unkown, result may greater 1, see also examples

title: Get the Conditional Error Rate for a intersection of hypotheses — get_cer
code: #the CER is high (even >1) if the p_values of the first stage are already low get_cer(  c(0.01, 0.01, 0.9, 0.9),  c(1, 1, 0, 0),  0.05,  matrix(rep(NA, 16), nrow = 4),  0.5 ) #> [1] 1.000138  #and lower otherwise get_cer(  c(0.01, 0.01, 0.9, 0.9),  c(0, 0, 1, 1),  0.05,  matrix(rep(NA, 16), nrow = 4),  0.5 ) #> [1] 0.0003088926

what: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
text: Generates data generating function give p-values unpaired t-test data generated multivariate normal distribution specified

title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
code: get_data_gen(   corr_control,   corr_treatment,   eff,   n_cont,   n_treat,   binary = integer(0),   bin_con_resp = NULL,   bin_treat_resp = NULL )

title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
text: corr_control correlation matrix control endpoints corr_treatment correlation matrix treatment endpoints eff vector effect sizes (.e. means) different treatment endpoints (compared control) n_cont number data points control endpoints n_treat number data points treatment endpoints binary treatment endpoints binary endpoints (control endpoints referenced also automatically treated binary) bin_con_resp response rate binary control groups bin_treat_resp response rate binary treatment groups

title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
text: function taking two arguments, see details

title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
text: gives back function, takes arguments number n multiarm_cer_design object returns matrix n * number treatments p-values. p-values generated drawing many data points specified design object given correlation mean, comparing t-test data points generated controls specified treatment_assoc design object.

title: Get a data generating function for simulating a trial — get_data_gen
text: Binary endpoints specified separately. Using means eff get used anymore endpoints, correlation endpoints still given, since binary endpoint calculated normal data. Additionally, currently assumes covariance binary endpoints (diagonal value correlations) 1 test used enpoints one-sided two-proportion z-test, tested outcome higher response rate treatment group.

what: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
title: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
text: Generates data generating function give p-values unpaired t-test data generated multivariate normal distribution specified arguments specification trials second stage

title: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
code: get_data_gen_2(   corr_control,   corr_treatment,   eff,   binary = integer(0),   bin_con_resp = NULL,   bin_treat_resp = NULL )

title: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
text: corr_control correlation matrix control endpoints corr_treatment correlation matrix treatment endpoints eff vector effect sizes (.e. means) different treatment endpoints (compared control) binary treatment endpoints binary endpoints (control endpoints referenced also automatically treated binary) bin_con_resp response rate binary control groups bin_treat_resp response rate binary treatment groups

title: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
text: function taking two arguments, see details

title: Get a data generating function for simulating the second stage of a trial — get_data_gen_2
text: function mostly works like get_data_gen(), see details data generation. However, instead specifing treatment control data size, taken specification second stage given multiarm_cer_design. Internally, resulting function uses get_data_gen() get suitable data generation function time called immediately uses generate data. Therefore, using get_data_gen() prefered performance standpoint whenever possible.

what: Get the time fractions for given sample sizes — get_t
title: Get the time fractions for given sample sizes — get_t
text: Get information time fractions planned interim test given trial arms, given sample sizes treatment control groups

title: Get the time fractions for given sample sizes — get_t
code: get_t(n_cont_1, n_cont_2, n_treat_1, n_treat_2)

title: Get the time fractions for given sample sizes — get_t
text: n_cont_1, n_cont_2 vector containing sample sizes control groups first second stage trial n_treat_1, n_treat_2 vector containing sample sizes treatment groups first second stage trial

title: Get the time fractions for given sample sizes — get_t
code: #trivial case with equal ratios throughout get_t(50, 50, 50, 50) #> [1] 0.5  #different sample sizes in the second trial stage, but constant allocation ratio get_t(   n_cont_1 = c(50, 50, 50, 50),   n_cont_2 = c(50, 75, 100, 150),   n_treat_1 = c(50, 50, 50, 50),   n_treat_2 = c(50, 75, 100, 150) ) #> [1] 0.5000000 0.4000000 0.3333333 0.2500000  #changing allocation ratio in the second stage: # the rate and number of control group patients stays the same, but treatment # group allocation is different get_t(   n_cont_1 = c(50, 50, 50, 50),   n_cont_2 = c(50, 50, 50, 50),   n_treat_1 = c(50, 50, 50, 50),   n_treat_2 = c(25, 50, 100, 150) ) #> [1] 0.6000000 0.5000000 0.4285714 0.4000000

what: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
title: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
text: Returns object class multiarm_cer_design. can used clinical trials multiple arms control groups might adaptations controlled using conditional error method.

title: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
code: multiarm_cer_design(   controls = integer(),   treatment_assoc = integer(),   n_controls = integer(),   n_treatments = integer(),   weights = double(),   t = double(),   alpha = double(),   test_m = matrix(),   alpha_spending_f = function() {  },   seq_bonf = TRUE )

title: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
text: controls Number control groups treatment_assoc Vector integer, corresponding number control group treatment group. length determines number treatment groups n_controls Integer (vector integers) determining number patients control group n_treatments Integer (vector integers) determining number patients treatment group weights List weights, measuring important hypothesis t information fraction, fraction assigned people interim analysis happen alpha Single number, measuring total alpha spent FWER test_m Transition matrix describing graph closed test procedure test hypotheses alpha_spending_f alpha spending function, taking parameters alpha (overall spent alpha) t (information fraction interim test) seq_bonf automatically reject hypotheses second stage sum PCER greater 1

title: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
text: object class multiarm_cer_design

title: Make a new multiarm CER trial design — multiarm_cer_design
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- multiarm_cer_design(  controls = 1,  treatment_assoc = c(1,1),  n_controls = 50,  n_treatments = 50,  weights = c(0.5, 0.5),  alpha = 0.05,  test_m = rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f = as,  t = 0.5)  design #> A Multi-arm Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.5 0.5 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.0  0.5 #> [2,]  0.5  1.0 #>  #> Number of control groups: #> [1] 1 #>  #> Treatment-to-control assignments (per treatment arm): #> [1] 1 1 #>  #> Planned sample sizes per control group: #> [1] 50 #>  #> Planned sample sizes per treatment group: #> [1] 50 50 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>

what: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
title: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
text: adapts multiarm design dropping treatment arm adjusting number datapoints

title: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
code: multiarm_drop_arms(   design,   arms,   n_cont_2 = NA,   n_treat_2 = NA,   alt_adj = FALSE,   adapt_bounds = TRUE )

title: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
text: design multiarm_design object arms list integers specifing arms dropped n_cont_2, n_treat_2 list number datapoints control treatment groups Can different different groups. lenght equal number control/treatment groups, including dropped treatments, always set 0 alt_adj uses cer_alt_drop_hypotheses() dropping hypotheses instead cer_drop_hypotheses() adapt_bounds Adapt bounds rejecting hypotheses keep FWER new adaptions, see cer_adapt()

title: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
text: weights dropped hypotheses set 0 distributed according prespecified graph, similarly cer_drop_hypotheses() specified, time fraction interim test also adapted according number data points second stage, assuming first stage n planned accoring t.

title: Drop arm from a multiarm design — multiarm_drop_arms
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- multiarm_cer_design(  controls = 1,  treatment_assoc = c(1,1),  n_controls = 50,  n_treatments = 50,  weights = c(0.5, 0.5),  alpha = 0.05,  test_m = rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f = as,  t = 0.5)  design <- cer_interim_test(design, c(0.1, 0.02))  design <- design |> multiarm_drop_arms(1) design #> A Multi-arm Design object, for testing 2 hypotheses at FWER 0.05. #>  #> ── Inital design specification ───────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> Hypotheses weights #> [1] 0.5 0.5 #>  #> Graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    1 #> [2,]    1    0 #>  #> Correlation for parametric test #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]  1.0  0.5 #> [2,]  0.5  1.0 #>  #> Number of control groups: #> [1] 1 #>  #> Treatment-to-control assignments (per treatment arm): #> [1] 1 1 #>  #> Planned sample sizes per control group: #> [1] 50 #>  #> Planned sample sizes per treatment group: #> [1] 50 50 #>  #> Interim test is planned at time fraction 0.5 #>  #> ── Interim test result ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> P-values of interim test are: #> [1] 0.10 0.02 #> No Hypotheses were rejected at the interim #>  #> ── Adaptions from inital specification ───────────────────────────────────────── #>  #> New hypotheses weights #> [1] 0 1 #>  #> New graph Transition Matrix #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    0    0 #> [2,]    0    0 #>  #> New correlation for parametric test #>      [,1] [,2] #> [1,]    1    0 #> [2,]    0    1 #>  #> Second-stage sample sizes (controls): #> [1] 25 #>  #> Second-stage sample sizes (treatments): #> [1]  0 25 #>  #> Total planned sample sizes after adaptation (controls): #> [1] 50 #>  #> Total planned sample sizes after adaptation (treatments): #> [1] 25 50 #>

title: Run a series of simulated trials according to a specified design — sim_trial
text: design cer_design multiarm_design object used simulation runs1 Number trials run first stage runs2 Number second stage run every first stage trial adapt_rule function takes cer_design object first interim test returns object appropiate adaptions data_gen_1 function generating first stage data, see details data_gen_2 function generating second stage data, see details include_designs boolean indicating whether include designs objects output

title: Run a series of simulated trials according to a specified design — sim_trial
text: dataframe containing various results

title: Run a series of simulated trials according to a specified design — sim_trial
text: data_gen_1 data_gen_2 take two arguments, number trials simulate adapted design object, return matrix dataframe row p-values single trial. See also get_data_gen() get_data_gen_2() information input output data generating functions look.

title: Run a series of simulated trials according to a specified design — sim_trial
code: as <- function(x,t) 2-2*pnorm(qnorm(1-x/2)/sqrt(t)) design <- multiarm_cer_design(  controls = 1,  treatment_assoc = c(1,1),  n_controls = 50,  n_treatments = 50,  weights = c(0.5, 0.5),  alpha = 0.05,  test_m = rbind(c(0, 1),               c(1, 0)),  alpha_spending_f = as,  t = 0.5)  adaption <- function(design) {   design |> multiarm_drop_arms(1) }  data_gen <- get_data_gen(   matrix(1),   rbind(    c(1, 0.5),    c(0.5, 1)  ),   c(0, 0.3),   100,   100 )  data_gen_2 <- get_data_gen_2(   matrix(1),   rbind(    c(1, 0.5),    c(0.5, 1)   ),   c(0, 0) )  sim_trial(   design,   5,   3,   adaption,   data_gen,   data_gen_2 ) #>    run1 rej_1 rej_2 rej_any p_1        p_2 interim_rej_1 interim_rej_2 #> 1     1 FALSE  TRUE    TRUE   1 0.01448593         FALSE          TRUE #> 2     1 FALSE  TRUE    TRUE   1 0.02949321         FALSE          TRUE #> 3     1 FALSE  TRUE    TRUE   1 0.01318780         FALSE          TRUE #> 4     2 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.61156774         FALSE         FALSE #> 5     2 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.52810949         FALSE         FALSE #> 6     2 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.83927697         FALSE         FALSE #> 7     3 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.07885208         FALSE         FALSE #> 8     3 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.06541350         FALSE         FALSE #> 9     3 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.02679034         FALSE         FALSE #> 10    4 FALSE  TRUE    TRUE   1 0.01389317         FALSE         FALSE #> 11    4 FALSE FALSE   FALSE   1 0.09854194         FALSE         FALSE #> 12    4 FALSE  TRUE    TRUE   1 0.02575248         FALSE 0.25244952         FALSE         FALSE #>    interim_p_1 interim_p_2 #> 1    0.3815457 0.001889621 #> 2    0.3815457 0.001889621 #> 3    0.3815457 0.001889621 #> 4    0.9800523 0.515780672 #> 5
